unnormalised: ## Return to Sender...Or Not? Decoding the Great Indian Return Policy Maze!
normalised: ## Return to Sender... Or Not? Decoding the Great Indian Return Policy Maze!

unnormalised: Let's be honest, navigating return policies these days is like trying to find a decent auto rickshaw driver at Connaught Place – chaotic and often leaving you feeling ripped off. We've all been there. You excitedly order that stunning Anarkali suit online, imagining yourself twirling like Madhuri Dixit at a Diwali party, only to find it looks more like a potato sack on arrival. Cue the return anxiety.

unnormalised: The first hurdle: actually FINDING the return policy. Buried deep within the website, often in a font size smaller than a mosquito, you discover the cryptic rules. Is it a 7-day return window? A 15-day exchange-only situation? Or worse, the dreaded "Final Sale" abyss? It's enough to make even Dr. Sharma, the calmest man in Gurgaon, start tearing his hair out.

unnormalised: And then comes the product condition clause. "Must be in original packaging, unworn, unwashed, and with tags intact." Seriously? How am I supposed to know that the saree's pallu will clash spectacularly with my mother-in-law's couch without actually trying it on? It's like expecting Sachin Tendulkar to score a century without even holding a bat!

unnormalised: Don't even get me started on the return shipping charges! Paying Rs. 200 to ship back a product that cost Rs. 500 feels like highway robbery. You start contemplating whether it's cheaper to just donate it to the local temple and call it karma.
normalised: Do not even get me started on the return shipping charges! Paying rupee two hundred to ship back a product that cost rupee five hundred feels like highway robbery. You start contemplating whether it is cheaper to just donate it to the local temple and call it karma.

unnormalised: Speaking of returns, remember that time Ramesh from Bangalore tried to return a 10 sq ft rug he bought online? Turns out, his cat had used it as a scratching post. Needless to say, the return was denied. He now uses it as a doormat, a constant reminder of his brush with return policy rejection.

unnormalised: So, next time you're online shopping, remember to read the fine print. And maybe, just maybe, pray to Lord Ganesha for a hassle-free return experience. Because in the world of Indian e-commerce, the return policy is a wild card – it can either save your sanity or drive you completely bonkers. Good luck, my friends, and may your returns be ever in your favor!
